field_reports.summary: JAM: Cyclone - 07-2024 - Hurricane Beryl  #2 (2024-07-05)
field_reports.description: As of Wednesday, July 3, 2024, the coastal sections of eastern parishes started to experience strong winds and surges. The eyewall of Hurricane Beryl moved just off the south coast of Jamaica, bringing heavy rains, storms surges, and flooding in some areas. The parishes most affected are Clarendon, Manchester and St. Elizabeth with small sections of other parishes recieving damage mainly from the winds. Approximately 1,000 persons occupied over 190 shelters  across the island. There are a number of persons who lost the roofs to their homes, however a final count is not available at this point. The agricultural sector was also affected.

contacts.name: Rhea Pierre
contacts.title: Acting Technical Lead - Disaster Risk Management

countries.society_name: Jamaican Red Cross
countries.name: Jamaica

field_reports.summary: JAM: Cyclone - 07-2024 - Hurricane Beryl
field_reports.description: As of July 1, 2024 at 8:00pm, a hurricane warning was issued for Jamaica as Hurricane Beryl enters into the Caribbean. Hurricane Beryl is currently at a category with maximum sustained of 165/mph, with expected fluctuations in strength and direction. There are several communities across the island that are expected to be impacted by strong winds, storm surge and floods as indicated by Office of Disaster Preparedness and Emergency Management (ODPEM). Electricity and water supply will be disrupted during and after the passage of Beryl as communicated by these service providers (Jamaica Public Service & National Water Commission)

contacts.name: Rhea Pierre
contacts.title: Technical Officer - Evolving Crisis and Disasters

countries.society_name: Grenada Red Cross Society
countries.name: Grenada

field_reports.summary: GRD: Cyclone - 06-2024 - Hurricane Beryl #1 (2024-06-30)
field_reports.description:
At 5:00 am June 30, 2024, the center of Hurricane Beryl was located near latitude 10.7 North, longitude 53.1 West, about 500 nautical miles east-southeast of Grenada. Beryl is expected to move across the Windward islands early on Monday. Currently, maximum sustained winds have increased to 100mph and rapid strengthening is forecasted. Information from the Meterological Services and NADMA advises that Grenada can expect to experience Hurricane conditions from Sunday evening in to Monday. The Northern part of the island (St, Patrick, St. Andrew, St. Mark, Carriacou and Petite Martinique) may be more severely affected. As such, subsequent to an emergency meeting held last evening of the National Emergency Advisory Council (NEAC), the following decisions were taken: 1) Emergency Shelters, district emergency operations centers and the National Emergency Operations Center will be activated from 12 noon on Sunday June 30, 2024 2) There is a scheduled water turn off from 9PM on Sunday 3) It is unlikely that there will be school on Monday as most schools are being used as hurricane shelters 4) Once the NEOC is activated at noon, there should be updates every 3 hours

UPDATE - JULY 1, 2024 - 6:45AM

Grenada is currently experiencing the effects of the outer bands from Hurricane Beryl. There are reports of rainfall, thunder, lightening and some high seas (varying degrees), however, no loss or damages reported thus far. Advisory from the Grenada Met Office relays that the hurricane is now located approximately 125 miles, 200KM ESE of Grenada with a 20 MPH speed. The effects is expected to intensify between the hours of 8AM and 8PM.

Last evening at 7PM the EOC was activated and a state of emergency was declared by the Government of Grenada (to be in effect for 7 days in the first instance unless otherwise advised). The team was at the EOC overnight monitoring the situation. Additionally, since the opening of the shelters approximately 2500 persons relocated to them across the tri-island state. Teams are assigned to these shelters, reports of 2 minor health related issues and blankets and other sleeping gears provided.

 

UPDATE - JULY 2, 2024 12:29PM

The tri-island state of Grenada, Carriacou and Petite Martinique was hit by category 4 Hurricane Beryl on July 1, 2024. Effects were felt from as early as 7AM and lasted throughout the day at different parts of the island. Hurricane force winds ravaged the North of Grenada along with the islands of Carriacou & Petite Martinique. Initial reports show widespread destruction with some houses completed damaged while others loss their roofs. The all-clear was given as of 8PM on July 1, however, the country remains under a state of emergency.

countries.society_name: Saint Vincent and the Grenadines Red Cross
countries.name: Saint Vincent and the Grenadines

field_reports.summary: VCT: Cyclone - 06-2024 - Hurricane Beryl
field_reports.description:
Hurricane Beryl poses significant risks and potential impacts to the Caribbean islands, particularly affecting St. Vincent and the Grenadines (SVG).   It is moving towards the west at 22mph (35km/h) with an increased maximum sustained winds of 80mph (130 km/h).  Hurricane  force  winds  extend  outward  up  to  10  miles  (20  km)  from  the  center,  and  tropical storm force winds extend outward up to 60 miles (95km). The effects of the winds could be felt from Sunday night.  Maximum sustained winds of 80 - 110 mph (129 – 177 km/h) or greater are expected across St. Vincent and the Grenadines, with possible higher winds offshore.   Rainfall accumulations of 4 to 6 inches (100 to 150mm) are likely across St. Vincent and the Grenadines.   Marine  conditions  are  expected  to  be  very  rough  and  hazardous  with  sea-swells  exceeding 4.0m (13ft) and possibly higher ~8.0m (26ft), near the center of ‘Beryl’ during Monday. Storm surges are possible across SVG.  Large and destructive waves/swells are likely to cause life-threatening surf and rip currents.   The government of St Vincent and the Grenadines has urged everyone to be prepared by putting together emergency supplies; shelters are to be activated by 6 p.m. and the NEOC activated at 8 p.m. on Sunday 30th June, 2024. The SVGRC continues to provide support  by continuously sharing updates on the weather and organizing volunteers to support shelter operations. In addition, volunteers were conducting walk through in their various communities, checking the vulnerable population and assisting families with preparation for the impending event.

Update: As at 12:00 p,m. on June 30, 2024, Hurricane Beryl has since intensified to a category four (4) hurricane with no change in its directed path. It is currently located at 260 mile ESE of St. Vincent and the Grenadines with the eye of the hurricane projected to pass between Grenada and the Grenadine Islands.  The hurricane force winds will extend up to 30 miles from the eye and the storm force winds will extend up to 115 miles. The populace of St. Vincent and the Grenadines will begin to feel the effects of the hurricane from midnight.  There are currently 817 persons in 34 shelters across St. Vincent and the Grenadines.

contacts.name: Rhea Pierre
contacts.title: Acting Emergency Focal Point and Technical Lead – Evolving Crisis and Disasters

countries.society_name: The Barbados Red Cross Society
countries.name: Barbados

field_reports.other_affected_pop_centres: St. Philip, Christ Church, St. John, St. Joseph, St. Andrew, St. Peter, St. Lucy
field_reports.summary: BRB: Cyclone - 06-2024 - Tropical Storm Beryl
field_reports.description: On the current projected track, the center of Beryl is expected to pass 45 km (26 miles) south of Barbados. The island is expected to feel the impacts associated with this system as early as late Sunday night, June 30, 2024. It is anticipated that the passage of Tropical Storm Beryl will bring strong winds that could cause damage to homes and properties. Additionally, flash flooding is likely across the island especially in flood-prone areas and severe thunderstorm activity may cause multiple interruptions to power utilities and services. It is anticipated that marine conditions will be hazardous ahead of and during the passage of Beryl. Tropical Storm Beryl has continued to strengthen and at 8am (Saturday 29th June, 2024) the system was located near 9.8N 46.8W or about 1570km (975 miles) east-southeast of Barbados. Some of the more densely populated parishes are likely to be directly impacted (St. Philip, Christ Church, St. Michael); as well as parishes that are particularly prone to flooding, tsunami threats and land slippage (St. Peter, St. Andrew, St. John and St. Joseph)

results.summary:
Since June 25, the National Hurricane Center began monitoring a tropical wave with the potential for development that was moving westward. By June 28, already transformed into Tropical Depression 2 / system AL95, it began to intensify due to atmospheric conditions and officially became Tropical Storm Beryl. 

The final conditions to become a hurricane happened on June 29, becoming the first major hurricane of the 2024 Atlantic hurricane season and the earliest category 4 hurricane to form in recorded history, on June 30. By July 1st it would become a category 5 hurricane with maximum sustained winds of 270 kmh.
results.name: Hurricane Beryl - Saint Vincent and the Grenadines, Grenada, Barbados and Jamaica

field_reports.summary: VCT: Other - 01-2024 - St. Vincent and the Grenadines Health Communicable Diseases
field_reports.description:
On January 10, 2024, the Ministry of Health, Wellness, and the Environment issued a press release providing updates on communicable diseases. The mentioned illnesses encompass COVID-19, Dengue Fever, Influenza (specifically Influenza A-HN1, commonly referred to as Swine Flu), and Leptospirosis. Notably, there were 32 confirmed cases of Influenza A-H1N1 between December 25, 2023, and January 6, 2024. In 2023, 243 cases of COVID-19 were reported, with only 2 cases documented in 2024. Dengue Fever had 17 confirmed cases, while Leptospirosis had 20 cases in 2023.

In a subsequent press release on January 16, 2024, the Ministry of Health announced an initiative to monitor leprosy cases in neighboring islands and enhance surveillance within St. Vincent and the Grenadines (SVG). Notably, SVG has not reported any leprosy cases in the past four years.

Recognizing the potential health emergency, the SVG Red Cross has initiated discussions with the Ministry of Health to assess potential areas requiring assistance. To address the situation comprehensively, a Surveillance meeting involving the Ministry of Health, Public Health Office, Epidemiologists, and other medical professionals is scheduled for the upcoming week. Following this meeting, the SVG Red Cross plans to collaborate with the Ministry of Health to determine specific areas and capacities where support can be effectively provided.

field_reports.summary: VCT: Cyclone - 2022-08 - Tropical Wave #2 (2022-08-04)
field_reports.description:
The tail of a passing Tropical wave impacted the South western parts of mainland St. Vincent and the Northern Grenadines of Bequia,  in the early hours of  Sunday July 31st morning.  The island experienced high gust of winds and rains of up to 33mph, thunder and lightening. Residents reported damages to roofs, power outages and blocked roads. 
UPDATE- NEMO reported 34 homes affected in St. Vincent and the Grenadines.  On the mainland 16 houses and 18 on the Grenadine island of Bequia.
Of the homes affected, 2 elderly males are displaced and staying at a government shelter on Bequia and 1 displaced staying with friends on the mainland.
The main damages sustained were to house roofs and a partially collapsed house.
A number of public buildings were also impacted with roof damages.

countries.society_name: Saint Vincent and the Grenadines Red Cross
countries.name: Saint Vincent and the Grenadines

field_reports.summary: VCT: Cyclone - 2022-07 - Tropical Wave Impact Southern St. Vincent and the Grenadines
field_reports.description:
The tail of a passing Tropical wave impacted the South western parts of mainland St. Vincent and the Northern Grenadines of Bequia.
The island experienced high gust of winds and rains of up to 33mph, thunder and lightening.
Unconfirmed reports of a collapsed house, Damages to roofs, power outages and blocked roads were reported.
The National Emergency Management office,  reported briefly  Roof Damages in the areas of Mainland communities of Belmont, Kingstown Park, Redemption Sharpes Trigger ridge. Northern Grenadines island of Bequia.  Assessments reports from the CDRT and Disaster Committee of that area are being conducted.
Unconfirmed pictures of damages to roofs are circulated on social media by private citizens. The Prime Minister addressed the nation of the impacts, which was not in any way extensive and in small pockets to roofs.

results.name: VCT: Cyclone - 2022-07 - Tropical Wave Impact Southern St. Vincent and the Grenadines

field_reports.summary: Tropical Storm Elsa Upgraded to a Hurricane. St. Vincent and the Grenadines
field_reports.description: At 8:am The Tropical Warning has been upgraded to a Hurricane Warning. At 8 am, the center of Hurricane Elsa was located near latitude 12.9° north; longitude 59.8° west, or approximately 95 miles (155 kilometers) east of Saint Vincent and the Grenadines. Maximum sustained winds have increased to near 75 mph (120 km/h) with higher gusts. The estimated minimum central pressure is 995 mb (29.38 inches). Movement is toward the west-northwest near 28 mph (44 km/h) and the center of the system is expected to pass near or over St. Vincent and the Grenadines late Friday morning. Sustained surface winds between 75 to 95 mph (120 to 152 km/h) with higher gusts are expected to spread across St. Vincent and the Grenadines this morning; persisting into the evening with light rain and pockets of intense showers and thunderstorm activities. Rainfall accumulations of at least 3 to 6 inches (75 to 150 mm) are possible with isolated higher amounts by tonight. Further accumulations of 2 inches (50mm) are likely by Saturday night. This rainfall could cause life-threatening flash floods and mudslides. Large northerly to south-easterly swells peaking near 5.0 meters (16 feet) are also forecast to accompany the system. Low-lying coastlines around the islands will be particularly vulnerable at times of high tide. High tide is expected at 1:01 pm today Friday 2nd July. Large waves and dangerous rip-tides can be expected. These will create unsafe conditions for small-craft operators and fishermen.

results.name: Tropical Storm Elsa Upgraded to a Hurricane. St. Vincent and the Grenadines

field_reports.summary: Tropical Storm Elsa - United States
field_reports.description:
Tropical Storm Elsa made landfall in Florida on July 07 and has inundated parts of the state with heavy rain and strong winds. The American Red Cross is helping those affected and urges everyone to follow storm safety steps.

Elsa carries 65 mph winds and could drop as much as nine inches of rain, causing flooding, downed trees, power outages and a storm surge along the Gulf Coast. The storm is expected to bring tropical storm conditions as far north as the mid-Atlantic states before heading out to sea Friday.

Trained Red Cross disaster workers have opened or are supporting as many as 20 shelters in Florida where more than 225 people escaped the storm Tuesday night.

field_reports.summary: Tropical Storm Elsa
field_reports.description: At 5am this morning – 1st July, Tropical Storm Elsa was formed and St. Vincent and the Grenadines was placed under a Tropical Storm Warning. At 5:00 p.m. today, the Centre of Tropical Storm Elsa was located near 11.2 N 53.8W or approximately 520 miles (835 kilometers) from St. Vincent and the Grenadines, with maximum sustained winds of 45 miles per hour (MPH) with higher gusts. Its present movement is to the West North West at 29 MPH. Rainfall accumulations of 3 to 6 inches (75 to 150 mm) with higher amounts in mountainous areas can be expected across St. Vincent and the Grenadines. This rainfall could cause life threatening flash floods and mudslides. On its present track, the centre of the system is predicted to pass near or over mainland St. Vincent by late morning or early Friday afternoon. Seas are expected to become very rough in open waters with swells peaking to near 5 metres (16feet).

countries.society_name: The Barbados Red Cross Society
countries.name: Barbados

field_reports.summary: Barbados - La Soufriere Volcanic Eruption Emergency Response
field_reports.description:
As a result of the eruption of La Soufriere Volcano in St. Vincent and the Grenadines, on Friday 9th April, 2021, Barbados has been experiencing heavy deposits of ash nationwide. In the initial days following the eruption (April 10th and 11th) the northern region of the island was most significantly impacted, although there was a downfall of ash nationwide. Heavy winds and the heavy ash fall complicated visibility.

Due to the direction of the wind, eruptions of La Soufriere have typically resulted in the arrival of heavy ash cover and downfall within 90 minutes to 3 hours from the time of the explosion.

The Barbados Meteorological Services issued a severe volcanic ash warning for the island on April 10, 2021.  There have been reports of ash fall across the island, and Saharan dust haze also remains present. This has led to reduced visibility and has caused respiratory problems, and heightened issues for persons with pre-existing respiratory challenges, or allergies.

 

Satellite imagery of the volcano continues to show a thick plume of ash traveling easterly towards Barbados in varying concentrations. 

 

The Grantley Adams International Airport (GAIA) was closed on April 10th, as a result of the Meteorological Office’s severe volcanic ash and small-craft warning. The airport will remain closed until at least noon on Friday, April 16, 2021. The Barbados Port Authority (Bridgetwon) was also closed on April 10.

On Sunday, April 11th, The Government announced the closure of businesses – with the sole exception being essential services, and limited opening of hardware stores.

The reopening of schools for Term III has been postponed by one week, and schools are now due to reopen on April 27th. Polyclinics also remain closed (as at April 4th, 2021) to allow for industrial cleaning of the sites.

contacts.name: Luann MC Guire
contacts.title: Disaster Management Director/ Community Programme Officer

countries.society_name: Saint Vincent and the Grenadines Red Cross
countries.name: Saint Vincent and the Grenadines

field_reports.summary: Volcanic Eruption
field_reports.description: The volcanic eruption caused disruption of services in many part of SVG. The supply of water, electricity, transportation was affected amongst others. Shelters were activated across the island and rescue operations in the Red Zone were occurring following the first eruption. There were several massive eruptions occurring thereafter the initial, with widespread ash fall on SVG and to the island to the east and north of SVG. The needs of the displaced citizens of SVG were reported as being of grave concern to Disaster Management officials on the Grenadine islands.

countries.society_name: Saint Vincent and the Grenadines Red Cross
countries.name: Saint Vincent and the Grenadines

field_reports.summary: St. Vincent and the Grenadines Volcanic Eruption
field_reports.description: The initial explosive eruption of La Soufriere continues, from last evening8-04-2021 as residents of the Red and Orange Zones are being evacuated. Evacuation continue via land transportation. LA SOUFRIÈRE BULLETIN #53 APRIL 09, 2021 -9:am 1. Scientists at the Belmont Observatory confirmed that there was an *explosive eruption at the La Soufriere Volcano at 8.40* this morning. 2. Ash plumes of up to 8 km were observed. 3. Ash fall has been recorded at the Argyle International Airport 4. All persons in the red volcano hazard zone are asked to evacuate immediately Ash plume up to 20,000 feet heading East. Second Explosion, created larger ash plume, evacuations continue as some residents are trapped it is reported ash fall created blockage of roads, from old Sandy Bay school back to Owia. Making traffic impassible

countries.society_name: Saint Vincent and the Grenadines Red Cross
countries.name: Saint Vincent and the Grenadines

field_reports.summary: St. Vincent and the Grenadines  La Soufriere Eruption
field_reports.description: The effusive eruption from La Soufriere increased activity, throughout today, as communities living on the volcano continue experienced tremors and volcanic earthquake on Easter Monday, began slowly evacuating. Residents reported heavy tectonics quakes and rumbling coming from the volcano. Earlier in today initial reports remained alert levels at ORANGE. This Level turned Red later today. National Emergency Bulletins reported; LA SOUFRIÈRE BULLETIN #49 APRIL 08, 2021 12:00 PM 1. The steaming/smoking at the La Soufriere Volcano has increased over the last few hours. 2. The alert level remains at Orange. The National Emergency Management Organisation is reminding the public that no evacuation order or notice has been issued. 3. Residents especially persons living in communities close to the volcano are encouraged to be prepared in the event that it becomes necessary to evacuate at short notice. 4. The National Emergency Management Organisation will continue to monitor the situation and provide updates as it becomes necessary. LA SOUFRIÈRE BULLETIN #50 APRIL 08, 2021 5:30 PM 1. An Evacuation Order has been issued for residents in the Red Hazard Zone of the La Soufriere Volcano. 2. The alert level has been elevated to RED. 3. Residents living in communities from Fancy to Georgetown, Fitz-Hughes, Chateaubelair and Petit Bordel are advised to self-evacuate, or prepare to be evacuated. 4. All shelters are being activated. 5. The National Emergency Operating Center (NEOC) has been fully activated and is operating around the clock. 6. NEMO is warning persons to desist from visiting the volcano at this time as it is very dangerous to do so. 7. NEMO will continue to provide updates as the situation evolves LA SOUFRIÈRE BULLETIN #51 APRIL 08, 2021 6:30 PM 1. The dome has now reached the height of the crater on the western (Leeward side) of the island. 2. Residents living on the Leeward side of the island will be able to see the glow/firey look of the dome as it gets darker. 3. The MV Gem Star is docked at the Chateuabelair Jetty to transport residents evacuating from the communites of Fitz-Hughes, Chateaubelair and Petit Bordel. 4. All residents of Fitz-Hughes, Chateaubelair and Petit Bordel who require transportation to get to the safe areas are asked to get to the Chateaubelair Jetty immediately to be evacuated. 5. The SVG Coast Guard is at the Chateaubelair Jetty to coordinate the sea evacuation process. Residents to be evacuated, via bus transportation, are stuck due to roads being blocked from private motorist evacuating out of the North Windward While assigned buses struggle to get in. Water facility shuts off water and fine ash sprays are seen as a haze across the North windward side of the island.

countries.society_name: Saint Vincent and the Grenadines Red Cross
countries.name: Saint Vincent and the Grenadines

field_reports.summary: St. Vincent and the Grenadines Volcano Activity
field_reports.description: The effusive eruption from La Soufriere increased activity, throughout today, as communities living on the volcano experienced tremors and volcanic earthquake. Residents queried why there were no reports of their experiences. NEMO and Professors of the seismic research center addressed their fears on VC3 local online radio. Residents indicated feelings of tremors , in this evening 24-3-2021 all residents reported accounts, around the hours of 4am, 8am, 11:am and 12:30 noon, the strongest at 5:56pm along with a rumbling was heard by the residents in the communities of Fancy, Owia, Sandy Bay, Magum/ overland. SCIENTISTS NOTED A CHANGE IN SEISMIC ACTIVITY ASSOCIATED WITH THE ONGOING ERUPTION OF THE LA SOUFRIÈRE VOLCANO. Monitoring scientists at the Belmont Observatory led by scientists from The UWI Seismic Research Centre (SRC) have noted a change in seismic activity associated with the ongoing eruption of the La Soufrière Volcano. Up until 23 March 2021, the seismic activity had been dominated by very small low-frequency events which were associated with the ongoing extrusion of the lava dome. These were almost always only recorded at the seismic station closest to the dome. Starting at approximately 10:30 local time (14:30 UTC) on 23 March 2021, the monitoring network recorded a swarm of small low-frequency seismic events which lasted for about 45 minutes. These events were different from previous activity in that they were also recorded on other stations. These events were probably associated with magma movement beneath the dome, although their depth cannot be determined. This is the first time that such a swarm has been seen since the seismic network was upgraded in early 2021.. Starting at 16:53 local time (20:53 UTC) on 23 March 2021, the monitoring network started recording volcano-tectonic (VT) earthquakes. These earthquakes are normally associated with underground fractures of the rock mass and are commonly generated by magma pushing through an unyielding rock mass. The volcano-tectonic earthquakes were located beneath the volcano, at depths down to 10 km below the summit. The largest of these had a magnitude of 2.6. Some of them have been reported felt by people living in communities close to the volcano such as Fancy Owia and Sandy Bay. At the present time the volcano-tectonic earthquakes continue, with the numbers of events fluctuating. The very-small dome-extrusion events also continue. The National Emergency Management Organisation (NEMO) wishes to inform the public that earthquakes associated with the ongoing eruption of the La Soufrière Volcano continue to occur from time to time and some of the largest ones may be felt. The alert level remains at Orange and no evacuation order or notice has been given. However, NEMO is encouraging residents especially person living in communities close to the volcano (i.e., the Red and Orange Volcanic Hazard zone), to heighten their preparedness in the event that it becomes necessary to evacuate at short notice. The La Soufrière Volcano continues to be closely monitored by a locally based team consisting of scientists from the Soufriere Monitoring Unit (SMU), The UWI Seismic Research Centre (SRC) and the Montserrat Volcano Observatory (MVO). This team work closely with an extended group based at the SRC (Trinidad) and MVO (Montserrat). The Team Lead at this time is Vincentian Professor Richard Robertson. The monitoring network use a variety of techniques to monitor the volcano that are constantly being improved and upgraded. Residents were advised the volcano is giving ample warnings and now is the time to prepare for the likelihood of an explosive eruption. The gas coming from the dome continue to cause damage to vegetation in the hillside areas on the south-western sides of the volcano. The gases within the plume are more acidic and can cause respiratory harm to human beings and have the potential to render one unconscious.

countries.society_name: Saint Vincent and the Grenadines Red Cross
countries.name: Saint Vincent and the Grenadines

field_reports.summary: St. Vincent and the Grenaindes Volcanic
field_reports.description: Magma continue to erupt effusively from La Soufriere. Satellite imagery, indicates the new black dome continue to increase in size , pushing to the previous crater walls. Bulletin No. 40- Satellite images of the crater from Sunday 7th March, 2021 indicated that the dome continues to grow. The gas coming from the dome has caused damage to vegetation in the hillside areas on the south-western sides of the volcano. The gases within the plume are more acidic and can cause respiratory harm to human beings and have the potential to render one unconscious. The gases can also have a corrosive effect on skin and eyes, even with short exposure. The processing of data collected from the Wallibou hot springs during last week indicated that there is no magmatic signature in the gases detected. The water samples have been dispatched to the United States for analysis. NEMO continues to appeal to the public to desist from visiting the La Soufrière Volcano, especially going into the crater, since doing so is extremely dangerous. As gases emit from the volcano and reaches the foot hills of the volcano National alert level remain at Orange. Surrounding communities in the red zone on 16th January,2021 were confused by the incandescent glow at night took to the streets running and evacuating, while NEMO and national radio calm public fears. UWI seismologist continue monitoring visits and from observatory station. The teams continue placing of seismic monitoring devices in strategic locations. NEMO with the assistance of CDRT and Community volunteers conducted a mapping and revised excavation muster points. Assessments conducted by NEMO also revised the vulnerable numbers in the Red and Orange Zone, for evacuation. Public Advisory continue daily/weekly, a total No. 41 bulletins to date. Nation wide volcanic risk communication and education campaign on various platforms continue. All agencies identified in the National volcano plan continue preparedness for warning of an explosive eruption and attend meeting with NEMO virtually UWI volcano ready project, support signage, Kids education,.

results.summary: On April 9, 2021 La Soufrière Volcano in Saint Vincent and the Grenadines (VCT) erupts explosively, releasing an ash plume 10km into the sky, displacing some 16,000 residents in the red and orange zones. In the following days, multiple eruptions occured, resulting in heavy ashfall in the surrounding areas, affecting people in St. Vincent and neighbouring islands of Barbados, St. Lucia, Dominica, and Grenada.
results.name: St Vincent & Grenadines - La Soufrière Volcano

field_reports.summary: St. Vincent and the Grenadines Volcanic Alert
field_reports.description: St. Vincent and the Grenadines active Volcano La Soufriere experiences activity in early November, 2020. The largest activity was a magnitude of 3.3. on 16th of December. On 27th December a hot spot was noted by NASA satellite in the middle of the crater.  Today seismic verified their is emissions of Magma, their was an explosion of a black mass from the pre-existing lake. The Mass is confined to the crater. Residents reported smoke coming from the volcano and smells of Sulfur. The current eruption is an effusive one confined to the crater. A new dome is growing on the side of the existing dome. The Country has been put on high alert-ORANGE. The Red zones from Fancy to Georgetown, in the North Windward and Belle Isle to Richmond in the North Leeward, are asked to prepare for an evacuation order. one has not been given this is only an Alert. The population at highest risk in the Orange and Red zone amount to 15,639 persons.

field_reports.summary: St. Vincent and the Grenadines Volcano Activity at La Soufriere
field_reports.description:
The La Soufriere volcanic activity continues to be an Effusive eruption. Last earthquake activity recorded 3.3. NASA alerted authorities on a hot spot at the crater, which shows magma erupting effusively and building a black Dome. The Alert Level nationally remains at ORANGE. The is Dome increasing in size. Surrounding communities reported smelling Sulfur and smoke rising from the volcano.  The Population at high risk are in the Red zone(Fancy to Georgetown in the North Windward and Belle Isle to Richmond in the North Leeward) 
Person visiting the volcano summit and posting to social media are being warned repeatedly via public advisory and Bulletins not to visit the summit of the volcano.
Water sources and evacuation measures are being assessed and prepared for a possible eruption.

results.name: St. Vincent and the Grenadines Volcano Activity at La Soufriere

field_reports.summary: St. Vincent and the Grendines Volcanic Activity
field_reports.description: Magma continue to ooze from the effusive eruption of La Soufriere. The Black Dome continue to increase in size, pushing to the previous crater walls.  National alert level remain at Orange. Surrounding communities in the red zone on 16th January,2021 confused by the incandescent glow at night took to the streets running and evacuating, seismologist and NEMO on national radio, tried to calm public. Public Advisory continue daily,  a total of 26 bulletins to date. Nationwide volcanic risk communication and education campaign on various platforms. All agencies identified in the National volcano plan continue preparedness for warning of an explosive eruption.
